4860, Macul Santiago Chile In the present work, the promoter effect of nickel over rhenium-supported catalysts was studied for the valorization of bio-oil model compounds. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption isotherms at −196 °C, temperature programmed reduction, NH3-temperature programmed desorption, CO chemisorption, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The catalytic performance was evaluated in a batch reactor at 350 °C and 50 bar of H2. The characterization results show that two phenomena occur with the inclusion of Ni through post-impregnation: A higher exposure of rhenium phases and formation of ReC and metallic Re at higher Ni contents and an electronic transfer from Ni to Re. The catalysts were evaluated for the hydrodeoxygenation reaction (HDO) of guaiacol used as a bio-oil model compound. The most active catalysts were the Re-Ni(3 %)/AC and Re-Ni(5 %)/AC samples. Cyclohexanol and cyclohexane were the main products obtained from the hydrogenation of phenol promoted by the reduced rhenium species. Graphical Abstract Keywords Rhenium Carbide Nickel Promoter Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Interest in sustainable chemistry research is continuously growing toward producing valuable chemicals and fuels from renewable resources, given the expected shortage of fossil-based resources [1]. In this context, lignocellulosic biomass stands out as a promising renewable carbon source for the chemical industry as it is associated with abundant reserves, eco-friendliness, and worldwide distribution [2]. Lignocellulosic biomass is predominantly constituted of cellulose, hemicelluloses, and lignin, and the transformation into value-added chemicals is currently the theme of biomass valorization [3]. The transformation into small organic intermediates, namely platform molecules, is essential to progress toward synthesizing fine chemicals, bio-oil, and biodegradable materials. Bio-oil is obtained with a high oxygen content; hence, it is necessary to generate processes that reduce oxygen content and improve its physical properties to obtain other products of interest. One alternative is the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [2] of bio-oil, which is studied employing model molecules, among which guaiacol is commonly used as a lignin-derived model compound because of its structure containing both phenolic hydroxyl and an ether bond [4]. In the HDO of guaiacol, some noble metals such as Ru, Pt, and Pd [5,6] are used as catalysts for guaiacol since they have good capacity in hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis. Precious metal catalysts have high HDO activity and selectivity, but their high cost and resource limitations have led to the search for other options. Transition metals such as Ni have also been studied, and the results show good hydrogenating activity [7,8]. Other active phases that have been studied are the oxides, nitrides, phosphides, and carbides. They have demonstrated a significant potential for the HDO of lignin-derived compounds because of the possibility of controlling their catalytic properties by modifying preparation methods, catalyst composition, and catalyst morphology. Among these groups, transition metal carbides have attracted considerable attention because they show catalytic activity like noble metals in various catalytic reactions. For the water–gas shift (WGS) reaction, Moon et al. [9] report that the Mo2C catalyst showed higher activity and stability than the commercial low-temperature shift LTS catalyst, even though both catalysts were deactivated during the thermal cycling runs. In hydrogenation, Quiroz et al. [10] report that supported molybdenum carbide (MoC) is an efficient catalyst to selectively convert levulinic acid into γ-valerolactone in the aqueous phase, reaching conversion and selectivity values higher than 99 % and 90 %, respectively. Rhenium carbide (ReC) has recently been studied to generate hydrogen from biomass and HDO of lignin model compounds. Blanco et al. [11] compared active carbon-supported ReC and MoC catalysts in HDO of guaiacol and observed that ReC was the most active and more selective toward BTX. Other recent studies also showed benzene formation in the guaiacol conversion using ReC as the active phase [12,13]. Therefore, it is essential to study the catalytic properties of this phase in greater depth and explore the use of promoters. For the synthesis of metal carbides, a carbon source is used along with methane, being one of the primary reactants used. Some studies have indicated that carbon supports can also serve as carbon sources. This method, known as carbothermal reduction, has been utilized with various support structures including activated carbon, carbon nanofibers, and carbon nanotubes [14]. For this purpose, activated carbon is presented as an excellent alternative as a support and source of carbon, given its surface characteristics and the presence of functional groups. On the other hand, some authors have studied the addition of promoters over some carbides to improve the catalytic activity in a series of reactions. Ji et al. [15] studied a series of Ni-promoted W2C catalysts for the catalytic conversion of cellulose into ethylene glycol (EG). The Ni-promoted W2C catalyst was very active and selective in cellulose conversion into EG, with a 100 % conversion of cellulose and a 73.0 % yield in EG. The authors indicated that the enhanced catalytic performance was due to the significantly higher dispersion of active sites on the catalyst after Ni inclusion. Rhenium carbide phases have shown high activity in HDO reactions. However, there are no studies on the use of promoters for rhenium carbides, particularly Ni, which has shown promising results as a promoter in other catalysts. Therefore, the main objective of this work is to study the impact of Ni used as a promoter in rhenium catalysts supported on activated carbon and evaluate their catalytic activity in the HDO reaction of guaiacol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis The catalysts were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation of a commercial activated carbon (Type CO-850, Petrochil S.A) followed by a thermal treatment. AC was first ground, sieved (< 150 μm), and dried for 2 hours at 110 °C. An aqueous solution of NH4ReO4 (provided by Molymet) was impregnated on the support (10 %wt Re content), left at ambient temperature, aged for 6 hours, and dried overnight at 90 °C. Then, it was carburized at 650 °C for 90 min under 75/25 of H2/C2H4 (%vol). The Ni catalyst was synthesized by support impregnation using an aqueous solution of Ni(NO₃)₂·6H₂O (Merck). After impregnation, the catalyst was left for maturation and subsequently dried overnight, as mentioned earlier. Following this, it underwent treatment at 350 °C under an inert atmosphere for 2 hours and was further subjected to reduction under H2 (100 mL min−1) at 350 °C for 4 h. The choice of 350 °C was with the objective of not modifying the formed carbide and the support [16]. The bimetallic catalysts were prepared by subsequent impregnation. For that, 10 %Re/AC, obtained with the previous treatment, was impregnated by an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2 at the desired nominal content (1, 3, and 5 % wt.), left for aging and dried under the conditions previously mentioned. Then, the obtained material was treated at 350 °C under N2 for 2 h and subsequently reduced under H2 at 350 °C for 4 h. Finally, all the catalysts were passivated at ambient temperature for one hour with a 5 % O2/N2 mixture (30 mL min−1). The resulting catalysts were labeled according to the metal nominal content Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3 and 5 %). 2.2 Characterization techniques Physical analysis was carried out using a 3Flex (Version 4.02) instrument from Micromeritics. Textural properties were obtained from the sorption isotherm of N2 at −196 °C. Prior, the sample (15–20 mg) was degassed for 4 hours at 300 °C under vacuum. The specific surface area was determined according to the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) theory from the adsorption using the Rouquerol criteria, and the total pore volume was defined as the single-point pore volume at p/p0 = 0.99. Micropore volume was determined by the t-plot method[17]. The phase identification and structural analysis of the samples were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Phillips X′Pert Diffractometer, with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5405 Å) as a radiation source at 45 kV and 40 mA. Diffraction patterns were obtained in a 2θ range from 20 to 70 (Bragg-Brentano geometry), where crystalline phases were identified with the JCPDS–ICDD 2003 database. Temperature-programmed analyses were carried out using the 3Flex (Micromeritics) combined with a mass spectrometer (Cirrus 2, MKS Spectra Product). Catalyst acidity was investigated by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD-NH3) under He flow. The sample (15–20 mg) was first pretreated for 30 min at 350 °C (10 °C/min) under He (50 mL min−1). Subsequently, NH3 (99.999 %) was switched to flow through the sample at 100 °C for 15 min (30 mL min−1) prior to desorption under He (100 mL min−1) at 10 °C/min until 600 °C. The total number of acid sites (mmol NH3/gram catalyst) was determined from the total amount of desorbed ammonia. The reducibility of the active phases and metal-support interaction was determined by temperature programmed reduction (TPR); the sample was heated at a rate of 10 °C/min until 1050 °C with a mixture of 5 % H2-Ar (100 mL/min). For CO chemisorption analysis, the samples were measured at 35 °C. Typically 30–50 mg of passivated catalyst was first degassed at 110 °C (10 °C/min) for 30 min and then reduced at 350 °C for 1 hour. The CO uptake was determined by subtracting two successive adsorption isotherms, with a one-hour degassing step between them. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using a SPECS® spectrometer with a PHOIBOS® 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer with angular resolution (< 0.5 degree) and a μ-FOCUS 500 X-ray monochromator (Al excitation line). The spectra were corrected when needed with the C 1 s peak (284.8 eV) to compensate for any charging effects. A Shirley-type background was subtracted using CasaXPS software (ver. 2.3.25) for analysis and chemical quantification. The fit was performed using Gaussian–Lorentzian curves (GL30). 2.3 Catalytic tests and product analysis Guaiacol HDO of Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3 and 5 %) were performed in a stirred-batch reactor (Parr Model 4590) of 300 mL for 4 h at 350 °C and a H2 pressure of 50 bar. These experimental conditions were selected according to previous results published by Blanco et al. [13,18]. In addition, to compare Ni(3 %)/AC catalyst was prepared with the same Ni impregnation treatment for Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) and evaluated in the guaiacol conversion. In a typical reaction, the reactor was loaded with 200 mg of catalyst, 5.1 g of guaiacol (Merck, 99 %), 96 g of dodecane (Merck, 99 %), and 1.6 g of hexadecane (Sigma, 99 %). The quantities were selected based on what was previously reported by Leiva et al. [19]. The reactor was purged for 15 minutes with N2 and heated to the reaction temperature with stirring (650 rpm). H2 was added during the reaction to maintain constant pressure. Small aliquots were periodically collected and quantified by gas chromatograph Nexis GC-2030 (Shimadzu) equipped with an Elite-1 column (Perkin Elmer, 30 m × 0.32 mm, film thickness of 0.25 μm). Conversion and product selectivity were defined according to the Eq. (1-3) (1) Conversion % = n products n guaiacol + n products * 100 (2) Selectivity % = n products ∑ n products * 100 (3) Carbon balance = n products + n guaiacol n guaiacol 0 The initial reaction rate r 0 (mol▪g−1s−1) was calculated from the initial slope (b) of the conversion (≤30 %) vs. time plot (s−1) according to the Eq. Turnover frequency (s−1) was calculated based on sites counted by CO uptake (μmol g−1) measurements: (5) TOF = r 0 CO uptake 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization 3.1.1 N2 adsorption/desorption Fig. 1a) shows the results of N2-sorption isotherms for support and catalysts. Fig. 1 shows that all samples had a high initial adsorbed volume, typical of type I isotherms associated with microporous materials. In addition, at high relative pressures, an increase in the adsorbed volume is observed, indicating the presence of slit-type micropores. Also, a hysteresis loop type H4 can be seen, indicating narrow slit-like pores according to the IUPAC classification [17]. Table 1 summarizes the textural properties of the support and catalysts. It can be seen that the specific surface of the activated carbon decreases with the impregnation of rhenium. This decrease can be directly related to the loss of micropore volume, suggesting that the metallic phase would be filling or partially blocking or the micropores of the support. With the impregnation of Ni to Re/AC, it is observed that the loss of specific surface is less pronounced and associated with higher micropore volume. Concerning the observed behavior, it is well known that carburization leads to graphitic carbon formation that could block or partially fill the micropore [20,21]. Furthermore, Ni is well-known for enhancing gasification reactions, therefore the addition of Ni and the subsequent reduction could promote graphitic gasification liberating some micropore blocked, and increasing the specific surface. This behavior was observed by Ma et al. [22] in the study of the promoting effect of Ni in MoxC catalysts. Up to a certain Ni content, an increase in specific surface area was observed, attributed to the presence of Ni favoring smaller particle size and therefore a larger specific surface area. This is in agreement with previously reported by Ji et al. [15], who studied the effect of Ni as a promoter in WxC phases, where they also observed a decrease in particle size with the inclusion of Ni. However, the increase in the area can also be attributed to the fact that Ni promotes the gasification of graphitic carbon at the time of reduction, which was formed in the carburization stage. This graphitic carbon has been reported to decrease the specific surface by blocking pores [23], therefore when it is gasified these pores are unblocked, increasing the specific surface. XRD Fig. 2a) displays the XRD patterns for Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %). For all diffractograms, two broad signals at 25° and 43° are observed and attributed to diffraction planes of amorphous carbon materials. For Re/AC and Re-Ni(1 %)/AC, the most intense signals observed are associated with ReOx phases. The low intensity peaks were better observed performing amplification of the 2θ axis in the range between 30° and 50° for the Re-Ni(1 %)/AC and Re/AC samples; the plot is provided as Fig. 2b). Signals between 30° and 50° are displaced with respect to the ReO 4 − patterns, suggesting the deformation of ReOx structure probably by the inclusion of carbon into the lattice. These results can be associated with the formation of an oxycarbide phase, as previously reported by Blanco et al. [13]. Then, when the Ni content increases to 3 % and 5 %, ReOx phases considerably decrease their intensity; this behavior could be associated with a decrease in the particle size of the Re species during the Ni inclusion process or to a better reduction of the ReOx phase. This result suggested that the introduction of Ni by post-impregnation could be promote a possible redispersion of Re species or the reduction of ReOx species. The phenomenon of redispersion has been previously reported, where the inclusion of a metal as a promoter improves the dispersion of metallic phases [15,24,25]. On the other hand, concerning the Ni phases, the appearance of a signal at 44° could be noticed for the 3 % content; that signal overlapped with others associated with the support, which can be related to Ni0 phases. Table 1 shows the values obtained for the crystallite size determined by the Scherrer equation. A decrease in crystallite size is observed at higher Ni contents, which indicates that the post-impregnation process favors the decrease in particle size by a redispersion of the phases as previously reported in other works. 3.1.2 TPR The results obtained from TPR profiles for passivated Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) catalysts are presented in Fig. 3. For all catalysts, it can be seen in Fig. 3a) two mainly H2 consumption signals: the first well-resolved signal is observed between 280–345 °C, except for Re-Ni(1 %)/AC (550 °C approximately), and the second broad signal in a range of 430–660 °C except for ReC-Ni(1 %)/AC (600–800 °C). The first peak could be associated with the reduction of ReOx species [26,27]. However, the second signal could be associated to various events, such as the support gasification [16] or the reduction of nickel or rhenium species making his discussion challenging. Nevertheless, some comments could be made. After the addition of 1 % of Ni, the TPR profile shifted to a higher temperature. This behavior could be due to a decrease of the particle size or stronger metal-support interaction. As the XRD results did not evidence any decreases of the particle size, it is proposed that the metal-support interaction has been enhanced by the addition of Ni, making the particle more difficult to reduce. Further increases in the Ni content, decrease the temperature of the TPR profile suggesting that, since in XRD no increases in the particle size could be observed, the metal-support interaction has been weakened. Fig. 3b) shows the CH4 production during H2-TPR for Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) catalysts. From the approach developed by Oyama et al. [28], the formation of the CH4 during TPR can be associated with different species based on the temperature: adsorptive carbon (200–300 ºC), carbide (460–490 ºC), reactive pyrolitic carbon (600–690 ºC) and unreactive graphitic carbon (700–800 ºC). For Re/AC two signals were observed, the first at 410 °C approximately, assigned to carbide species, and the second broad signal at around 800 °C, which could be related to pyrolytic carbon. In the case of Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) catalysts, it is observed a broad signal in a range of 400–800 °C that increases in intensity with Ni content, this signal could be associated with carbide and pyrolytic species, and the increase in intensity is associated with the support methanation catalyzed by Ni [12,28]. Also, a shoulder observed at 410 °C approximately can be assigned to carbide species. The deconvolution of the signals shows an increase in the number of species that decompose mainly in the range between 400 and 600 °C. These results indicated that the presence of Ni increases the ReC species and the decomposition of other carbon species present in the support, which modified the reduction of Re species. Fig. 3c) shows the MS CO signal for Re catalysts since the formation of CO can be related to the carburization degree [12]. For comparison, the MS CO signal for carburized support is included because some signals can be associated with oxygenated functional groups remaining after thermal treatment of the support. For AC carburized, a broad signal is observed that begins at 750 °C approximately, which is associated with functional groups that were stable at the carburization temperature. Then, for Re/AC, a broad signal is also observed, but that signal begins at approximately 650 °C, and finally, for the catalysts promoted with Ni, the broad signal shifts again to lower temperatures, reaching 600 °C. Signals at temperatures lower than 750 °C for Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) are associated with the appearance of species that generate CO. In this case, it could correspond to a rhenium oxycarbide, indicating a partial carburization of Re [29]. When comparing Re/AC with catalysts promoted with Ni, an increase in the signals associated with oxycarbides is observed. This behavior shows that the inclusion of Ni increases the degree of carburization of rhenium species [12]. 3.1.3 NH3-TPD The acid properties for passivated catalysts were measured using NH3-DTP, and Fig. 4 displays the obtained MS-NH3 desorption profiles. A negligible desorption profile is observed for both AC and Re/AC samples. For catalysts promoted by Ni, a signal between 100 °C to 250 °C associated with weak acid sites was observed [30,31]. No changes in the signal associated with weak acid sites are observed with Ni content; the three promoted catalysts present similar sites. The increase in acidity is not caused by the Ni content or the functional groups of the support. Instead, it is due to the reduction treatment of the catalyst after Ni impregnation. This treatment promotes the creation of vacancies of rhenium species that were not carburized [27]. These vacancies should have a Lewis acid nature. 3.1.4 X-ray photoelectronic spectroscopy (XPS) Fig. 5 and Table 2 show the XPS spectra obtained from the Re 4 f and Ni 2p3/2 core-levels of passivated Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) catalysts. The deconvolution of the Re 4 f signal from Re/AC showed two minor contributions at 40.8 eV and 42.1 eV, which can be attributed to Re carbide [11] and Re4+ species in ReO2 [12], respectively. Then, at higher binding energies, the two largest contributions are observed at 45.2 and 46.4 eV associated with Re7+ with oxygen vacancy and Re7+ [19,32]. For Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3 and 5 %), contributions at 40.3, 41.7, 43.6 eV and 46.0 eV were observed for all promoted catalysts, which can be associated with Re0 [33], Re3+ [34], Re6+ [35] and Re7+ in Re O 4 − [19] respectively. These results indicate that with higher Ni content, the reduction of Re species is favored, leading to the formation of Re0, which was not observed in Re/AC and Re-Ni(1 %)/AC. Another trend observed is the shift to lower bond energies of the signal attributed to Re+7 with the inclusion of Ni, this could be related to the fact that Re could be receiving electronic density from Ni. On the other hand, for Ni 2p3/2 core-level three main contributions can be observed for ReC-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) at 852.9 eV, 855.8 eV and 857.2 eV. The signal at 855.8 eV can be attributed to Ni2+ which was not reduced [36]. Regarding the signal at 857.4, this can be associated with Ni3+ in NiOOH [34,37]. Signals above 860 eV correspond to the satellite signals of Ni oxides [38,39]. For the first signal for Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3 and 5 %), the value is slightly shifted to higher binding energies to the values reported for the metallic Ni species, which are between 852.6 and 852.7 eV [40–42], for this reason, this signal corresponds to a type of metallic Ni with lower electron density. The shift observed in the case of Re confirms the interaction of Re with Ni, as it can be directly related to the loss of electron density. This behavior has been previously reported by Yang et al. [43] indicating that Re reduces the electronic density of Ni because the d band of Re receives charge from the d band of Ni, for this reason, the displacements observed in the levels studied for Re (4 f) and Ni (2p) are small. To summarize, XPS results indicated that during Ni impregnation it favors the formation of ReC species and the interaction of Re-Ni at higher Ni contents. Table 2 also shows the surface abundance of each species expressed as a percentage. As previously mentioned, the increase in Ni content leads to reduced Re species, and surface percentages indicate that the main species formed is ReC, reaching practically 50 % for Re-Ni(3 %)/AC and Re-Ni(5 %)/AC. This result indicates that during the Ni impregnation process, the carburization of Re is favored with Ni content. The increase in reductive carboxylation (ReC) occurs during the reduction stage, which takes place after the impregnation of Ni. As observed by H2-TPR MS, the presence of Ni favors the decomposition of support, generating methane, which acts as a carbon source for the formation of ReC. In addition, surface atomic ratios were calculated, and the results are summarized in Table 2. The results show a surface atomic ratio of 0.063 for Re/AC, 0.061 for ReC-Ni(1 %)/AC, 0.090 for ReC-Ni(3 %)/AC, and 0.076 for Re-Ni(5 %)/AC. These results indicated that Re-Ni(3 %)/AC and Re-Ni(5 %)/AC catalysts have a higher proportion of Re exposed on the surface. 3.1.5 Catalytic properties Table 3 presents the initial reaction rate for the different catalysts. These values showed a tendency to increase with the Ni content, reaching their maximum value for Re-Ni(x)/AC (3 % and 5 %). In the case of Ni(3 %)/AC, this has a lower initial rate than Re/AC and, is much lower than the values obtained for the promoted catalysts. These results show that the inclusion of Ni as a promotor affects on the catalytic activity of the Re species in the guaiacol conversion. However, further increases in Ni content to 5 % did not further increase the initial rates. In addition, TOF was calculated from CO uptakes to determine the activity per active site, and the results are shown in Table 3. The TOF values show a difference in the activity per active site for the Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 0, 1, 3, and 5 %) catalysts. This behavior suggests that these catalysts exhibit distinct active phases which is consistent with the XPS results. The increase in catalytic activity with the inclusion of Ni can be associated with three phenomena: first, the increase in active species exposed on the surface, observed in the surface ratio values by XPS. The second phenomenon is the formation of reduced Re species, since by XPS, evidence on the formation of metallic Re and the increase in ReC species for Re-Ni(3 %)/AC and Re-Ni(5 %)/AC catalysts was observed. Those samples resulted in the more active materials evaluated. Finally, the third phenomenon is the Re-Ni interaction observed by XPS, which could indicate a synergistic effect between both species. The catalyst Re-Ni(3 %)/AC, demonstrates significantly higher catalytic activity compared to other metal carbide catalysts. This is outlined in Table S1 in the supplementary material. As different active phases could be detected, different product distributions could be expected. Fig. 6 shows the product selectivity at 20 % conversion for Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) catalysts, comparing them to Ni(3 %)/AC. In the case of Re/AC, the main product is phenol with a 68 % yield, followed by 2-methylanisole and o-cresol, both reaching a yield close to 7 %. Finally, anisole, cyclohexanol, cyclohexane, and benzene appear, reaching a total yield of 10 %. Previous studies by Leiva and Ghampson found that guaiacol conversion over supported ReOx primarily yields phenol due to the ReOx phase's propensity for C–O bond scission[19]. However, they did not find 2-methylanisole and o-cresol as secondary products; instead, they observed benzene and cyclohexane. This could be attributed to the strong dependence of product distribution on the surface properties of the support. For Re-Ni(1 %)/AC, it can be observed that, once again, the main product is phenol with a 66 % selectivity. However, cyclohexanol appears as the second product, reaching a 20 % selectivity. Other compounds, such as o-cresol, cyclohexane, and benzene, among others, do not exceed a 5 % selectivity. The Re-Ni(3 %)/AC catalysts exhibited a similar behavior to Re-Ni(1 %)/AC, where phenol is the main product with a 55 % selectivity, followed by cyclohexanol with 27 %. In the case of Re-Ni(5 %)/AC catalyst, the main product is phenol with a 48 % selectivity. However, it achieves the highest formation of cyclohexanol with a 35 % selectivity, followed by a minor formation of 2-methylanisole, o-cresol, and others, resulting in a total selectivity of 16 %. Cyclohexanol production in catalysts promoted with Ni can be related to the Re-Ni interaction which favors the stage of hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanol and cyclohexane. This behavior agrees with that reported by Park et al. [37], who indicated that the interaction Ni-Re favors the anchoring of C-O bonds over C-C bonds, increasing the selectivity towards deoxygenated products such as cyclohexane. This was associated with the modification of the electronic states of the species [43]. On the other hand, an increase in cyclohexanol formation with Ni content may be associated with the increase in carburized Re species, as observed by XPS, where Re-Ni(5 %)/AC presents the highest proportion of carburized Re species [44,45]. Conversion as a function of time for Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3 and 5 %) catalysts are presented in Fig. 7. For the Re/AC, the formation of phenol is mainly observed, which increases during the reaction, reaching a 35 % yield. In addition, the formation of other products, such as 2-methylanisole and o-cresol, is observed, and they reach a yield of approximately 5 %. Then, for Re-Ni(1 %)/AC, the formation of phenol is also observed, which increases until reaching a 50 % yield at the end of the reaction. The formation of cyclohexanol is also observed, which increases constantly during the first 3 hours of the reaction, but an increase in the formation curve is observed at the end of the experiment, reaching 30 % yield. Finally, Re-Ni(3 %)/AC and Re-Ni(5 %)/AC present a similar behavior. It is observed that phenol is quickly formed, reaching a 30 % yield, which is consumed before the first 60 minutes of reaction. A few minutes later, the formation of cyclohexanol is observed, which reaches 70 % yield after 60 minutes of reaction and then begins to be consumed during the reaction, remaining at approximately 35 % yield at the end of the reaction. Finally, after about 40 minutes of reaction, cyclohexane formation begins, reaching a 45 % yield. Regarding the phenol formation, Nimmanwudipong et al. [46], reported that selectivity for phenol formation implies that deoxygenation by removal of the methoxy group is more favorable than deoxygenation by removal of the hydroxyl group. Then, the formation of cyclohexanol and cyclohexane indicates that the reaction follows the phenol hydrogenation route. In this sense, guaiacol HDO over Re/AC and Re-Ni(x)/AC (x = 1, 3, and 5 %) catalysts follows a conversion path that coincides with previously reported works [6,7,26] and which is shown in Scheme 1. In the first stage, guaiacol can be converted mainly via two independent routes: via demethoxylation or via dehydroxylation to form phenol or anisole, respectively. The demethoxylation step is favored by acidic sites, while metal sites promote dehydroxylation. In the secondary stage, ring hydrogenation can convert phenol to cyclohexanol. Then, cyclohexanol is converted to cyclohexane through dehydration. Another option is to convert phenol to benzene via dehydroxylation, and then, the ring hydrogenation and subsequent dehydration of benzene form cyclohexene through hydrogenation from cyclohexane. Finally, phenol could also be transformed into o-cresol via methylation, and o-cresol can convert to toluene via deoxygenation favored by metal sites. The results obtained over Re/AC catalysts in agreement with other metal carbide studies previously reported [27,47]. For Ni-promoted catalysts, increase the guaiacol conversion, reaching 80 % for Re-Ni(1 %)/AC and 100 % for Re-Ni(x)/AC (3 % and 5 %). In the case of Ni(3 %)/AC catalyst, the value of guaiacol conversion is similar to that obtained for the Re/AC sample, but is lower than the conversions obtained for the promoted catalysts. Figure S1 displays the results from the recycling processes using the most active catalyst, Re-Ni(3 %)/AC. It is evident that the catalyst maintains its activity after the initial reaction; however, a subsequent decrease in the conversion of approximately 30 % is observed during the second recycling. 4 Conclusions The present work studied the Ni promoter effect on rhenium catalysts supported in activated carbon for HDO of guaiacol. The results show that during the reduction stage after impregnation, the formation of carburized rhenium species is favored because the support decomposition, catalyzed by Ni, generates CH4, which acts as a carbon source for Re carburization. Other species that form during reduction are metallic rhenium and ReC; both are favored at higher Ni contents. In addition, XPS results, seem to indicate a phenomenon of higher exposure of the Re active species at the surface. And some electronic transfers from Ni to Re could be detected. The most active catalysts in guaiacol HDO were Re-Ni(3 %)/AC and Re-Ni(5 %)/AC, which reached 100 % conversion before 60 min of reaction. This behavior could be explained by three phenomena: a higher exposure of surface active sites, a synergetic effect between Re and Ni, or/and to an increase of ReC species. The main products obtained in the HDO of guaiacol over these catalysts were cyclohexanol and cyclohexane, which was related to the Ni-Re interaction and ReC species that favored the formation of phenol and the subsequent hydrogenation of the aromatic ring. coredata.dc:description: In the present work, the promoter effect of nickel over rhenium-supported catalysts was studied for the valorization of bio-oil model compounds. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption isotherms at −196 °C, temperature programmed reduction, NH3-temperature programmed desorption, CO chemisorption, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The catalytic performance was evaluated in a batch reactor at 350 °C and 50 bar of H2. The characterization results show that two phenomena occur with the inclusion of Ni through post-impregnation: A higher exposure of rhenium phases and formation of ReC and metallic Re at higher Ni contents and an electronic transfer from Ni to Re. The catalysts were evaluated for the hydrodeoxygenation reaction (HDO) of guaiacol used as a bio-oil model compound. The most active catalysts were the Re-Ni(3 %)/AC and Re-Ni(5 %)/AC samples. Cyclohexanol and cyclohexane were the main products obtained from the hydrogenation of phenol promoted by the reduced rhenium species.
